audio_caption: The clip begins with a friendly greeting, as one man announces the topic of his tutorial, promising tips and tricks for filming a music video, and invites listeners to support his channel via the links below. This introduction is followed by a short piece of upbeat, pop-influenced instrumental music.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker, who sounds friendly and enthusiastic, explaining the "golden rule when filming a music video." He describes capturing lots of footage from different angles, and then introduces a "safety shot," describing it as an angle to cut to when problems arise. He sounds relieved that he got it, as he ended up needing it. He then goes on to describe putting the camera onto a slider mounted on a tripod, and using a Canon lens for a wide shot. The clip ends with the speaker mentioning he's done reviews of the lenses used for the music video, which are linked below.

The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining a camera setup, including using a "Zeun Crane Gimbal," a "Canon 35 mil F2 IS" lens, and how he adjusted the aperture for specific shots. He describes walking around a band cherry-picking instruments, followed by capturing the singer with a strip light. The speaker sounds conversational and technical.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, enthusiastic and informative, describing a camera slider setup and lens choices for a music video shoot, focusing on the drummer's active role and the guitarist's complex solos. He also mentioned handheld and slider shots of details, such as the drummer's cymbals and bassist's keyboard, along with instrument close-ups.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a music video shoot. He describes how he shot the singer of a band in a different environment, using a gimbal and a 35mm lens in a country lane, creating a "walk and follow shot." He mentions that the band preferred their "instruments do the talking," and that they didn't want the video to end up "looking like a Backstreet Boys turned rock band video." No music is heard in this audio clip.

The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining the lighting setup for the video. He describes the setup as simple, mentioning a two-light arrangement with one behind the camera and another behind the drums, which he wanted to have a "hard light". He expresses a preference for backlighting and summarizes the lighting approach as "very simple, quick and easy".

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining that the video was edited in Final Cut using the multicam feature. He then mentions he has a separate video about the multicam feature, which will be linked below. He shifts the conversation to the color grading of the footage, introducing what's coming. A short musical stinger plays.

The clip starts with a male speaker talking about an easy video to grade because of "good lighting" and the exposure being "exactly where I wanted it to be," continuing on in a conversational and informative tone about using multicam and advising to watch his previous video for help. He says that the "first thing" he will do is add an instance of "color wheels," further explaining that he is going to drop the exposure a "little bit" because it is "overexposed" and for the purpose of "keeping the noise down." The clip concludes with a soft "click" sound.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing adding a lookup table to his work, mentioning using "Phantom Luts" and preferring monitor luts. He adds a vignette for a rock band to achieve a contrasty and moody look. He adjusts the vignette's parameters, tweaking the contrast and saturation while turning off the blur for a more natural effect, aiming for a subtle darkening around the edges. The speaker adopts a casual speaking tone throughout the audio clip.

The clip features one male speaker who starts by explaining the addition of a "letterbox" to achieve a specific aspect ratio and emphasizing the need to adjust the footage to avoid cropping. He continues, outlining adjustments to color wheels, pushing shadows to a "teely blue" and warming the midtones. He mentions the absence of sharpening due to the use of sharp lenses and filming in 4K, indicating it was unnecessary. He states that his approach was consistent across all shots, with minor color matching adjustments as needed and encourages feedback.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker expressing hope that the video was helpful and interesting, mentioning a "large back catalog" of videos. He states that YouTube is recommending one video for the listener, and his latest upload will be underneath. The speech has a helpful and informative tone.

The clip begins with an encouraging male speaker promoting his channel, suggesting viewers "hit the blob" and to "help each other out and shoot better videos". This transitions to music with a moody, almost melancholic tone, featuring electronic elements and vocals. The male vocalist can be heard singing "it carries me" and "since I'm alone, my body's holding me".
